ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES



Hunt Southland Refining Company (HSRC) Sandersville Refinery has a commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel and considering safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of our processes. Our policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. However, if a release does occur, our trained personnel will respond to control and contain the release.



DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES



HSRC's Sandersville Refinery located in Sandersville, Mississippi operates a variety of processes to produce petroleum products, primarily asphalt related, from raw crude oil. Within the refining industry we are known as a topping operation in that our focus is on the 50% to 55% of the barrel of crude which is asphalt.  The remaining fractions of the crude barrel are primarily used as feedstock for Sandersville's sister refinery.   The Sandersville refinery is considered small by industry standards with a maximum capacity of 12,500 barrels per day. 



Sandersville Refinery's light straight run, a mixture of flammable materials that contains regulated substances butane, n-pentane, and isopentane in quantities greater than 1%, is the stationary source's only process covered by EPA's Risk Management Plan (RMP) rule.  Light straight run is produced in the crude distillation process and stored in tanks on site before it is transferred offsite for further processing.    



(Note:  When reporting in RMP*eSubmit, only one chemical and its amount can be selected per process for each worst case scenario.  Because of this, the worst case scenario is listed as the quantity of n-pentane released; however, the entire weight of the flammable mixture was used to model the distance to endpoint.)  



GENERAL ACCIDENT PREVENTION STEPS



Sandersville Refinery has

developed a process safety management (PSM) program for processes that represent the greatest risk to its employees and the public per OSHA's PSM regulations and the EPA's RMP rule.   



Sandersville Refinery has an Employee Participation plan that describes how employees are involved in an ongoing basis with implementation of each of the fourteen elements of the stationary source's PSM program.  For example, employees are involved in writing and reviewing procedures, participate in process hazard analyses (PHA) and incident investigations, as well as on the plant emergency response team (PERT).  Safety suggestions are also collected on an informal basis and communicated with management.  



Process safety information for the light straight run process is compiled in the Sandersville Refinery PSI manual, which is maintained by site engineering personnel and made available to employees both in hard copy and electronically.  In addition to typical hazard communication information, documents are also kept on key process parameters, piping and instrumentation diagrams, chemical mixture, technical manuals for key equipment, and industry guidelines for safe operations in petroleum refineries.



An initial process hazard analysis was conducted for the light straight run process and is revalidated at least every five years.  The primary methodology for this analysis is the "what if" method, which is appropriate for bulk storage facilities.  Any recommendations from the PHA are reviewed by management and implemented as soon as practicable.   



Sandersville Refinery employees are also subject to extensive training for both routine operations of the refinery as well as emergency operations.  Operators are trained initially on their operating procedures, safe work practices, and the hazards of the process and are required to refresh at least every three years.  



Sandersville Refinery relies on contract maintenance and construction employees on a routine basis.  Contrac

t companies must meet specific safety and health criteria prior to selection and are subject to plant-specific orientation before working on plant process equipment.  Contractors are expected to know and follow Sandersville Refinery's safety standards and to work under the oversight of a Sandersville Refinery supervisor at all times while in the plant. 



Sandersville Refinery has also developed numerous risk management and safe work practices to prevent releases of regulated substances.   These include:

 - An inspection, testing, and preventative maintenance plan to ensure the ongoing mechanical integrity of the light straight run process equipment, which includes the proper operation and maintenance of the tank's internal floating roof, rotating equipment, and piping.  

 - Safe work practices such as lock-out / tag-out, line breaking procedures, permit-required confined space entry procedures, hot work permit procedures, and control over entry into process areas to minimize potential for releases during maintenance activities.

 - Management of change and pre-startup safety review procedures to evaluate proposed changes to the process safety information for the light straight run process and verify equipment is ready for service following significant changes.



Accident and incident investigations are also conducted whenever there has been an accident, near miss, or other incident.  Where a potential for catastrophic release is identified, causal factors are evaluated and corrective actions implemented to reduce the likelihood of future releases.  



A compliance audit as required by OSHA's PSM standard is conducted at least every three years and includes the light straight run process.  An action plan is generated to address any audit findings.  



CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



The light straight run storage tank is located in secondary containment.  It has an internal floating roof that is critical to minimizing flammable vapors in the tank.  The s

torage tank is also gauged every four hours.  During this gauging the tank is inspected for problems or weakened components.  The key element of release containment, control, and mitigation is the permanent foam chamber installed in the roof of the storage tank.  External monitors and other fire suppression equipment are stored near the vicinity of the tank.  Operators are trained to respond in the event of a small release, such as a pump seal failure, and have authority to shut down the process if a hazardous condition occurs.  



FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



There have been no accidents or incidents in the last five years related to the light straight run process that require reporting in the five-year accident history.  



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION



Sandersville Refinery maintains an emergency response program that includes a plant emergency response team (PERT).  The program covers a variety of regulatory requirements in addition to RMP including TIER II reports for EPCRA, emergency action plans, emergency response plans, SPCC plans, pipeline spill response plans, and process safety management plan.



All employees are trained under OSHA's 24 Hour Hazardous Waste Operator Standard and go through fire brigade training as well.  Emergency response courses are conducted on a monthly basis throughout the year.   Sandersville Refinery also periodically coordinates with local emergency responders.  This includes conducting on-site table top and field drills.  



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



Sandersville Refinery is currently engineering a safety-instrumented system that will reduce the likelihood of releases of flammable materials to the atmosphere during certain upset operating conditions.  Installation is anticipated for the next unit turnaround.
